questions.text: Which of the following public health centers do First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to?
questions.solution:
First Referral Units (FRUs) and non-FRUs belong to the Community Health Centers (CHCs). 

The Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) guidelines are a code of standards for uniformity in health facilities in the Indian public health system, under the National Health Mission (NHM), Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW), India. It aims to provide guidance on the infrastructure, human resources, drugs, diagnostics, equipment, quality, and governance requirements for delivering health services at all levels of facilities in the system.

The 2022 edition of IPHS mainly concentrates on comprehensive primary health care, increasing the human workforce, decentralized access to healthcare, and better implementation of universal health coverage.

Related Pearl: Levels of Healthcare System in India

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: A district has a population of 20 lakhs. According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, approximately how many beds should the district public health system have for this population?
questions.solution:
In a district having a population of 20 lakhs, the number of beds the district public health system should have is given as follows: 2000 essential and 4000 desirable.

According to IPHS 2022 norms for the number of beds in district hospitals, 1 bed per 1000 population is essential and 2 beds per thousand population would be desirable.

Therefore, in a population of 20,00,000 the district public health system should have 2000 essential and 4000 desirable beds.

The essential number of beds should be achieved through the public health system of tertiary care (medical colleges), secondary care (DH, SDH, CHCs), and primary care in the district (PHCs and CHCs).

questions.text: You are involved in the planning for a hospital in your district. If you decide that the minimum number of essential beds is 50, what should the population of your district be, according to the IPHS 2022 guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, a minimum number of 50 essential beds would be required for a district with a population of less than 2 lakhs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about district and sub-district hospitals?

choices.text: All districts need at least two district hospitals.
The minimum essential number of beds in a sub-district hospital is 100.
All districts do not need a sub-district hospital.
DNB training can be done in district hospitals.

questions.solution:
Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning district hospital (DH).

District hospitals and subdistrict hospitals provide secondary care health services. Every district should have at least one comprehensively functioning DH. Districts with a population of less than 5 lakhs and with a functional DH do not need a subdistrict hospital (SDH). Districts with a population of 5–10 lakhs can have one SDH. For a population of more than 10 lakhs, 1 SDH is needed for every 10 lakh population.

The three pillars of district hospital services are providing clinical care, providing a knowledge hub for capacity development, and public health programs.

Important functions of DHs:

  • Providing curative services
  • Palliative and rehabilitative services
  • Implementation of health programs
  • Drugs and diagnostic services
  • Administrative and other support services
  • Health promotion and prevention, education
  • Providing educational services, like Diplomate of National Board (DNB) training; training courses for healthcare professionals (HCPs) in auxiliary nursing and midwifery (ANM), telemedicine, and technology; and partnerships with universities

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Community Health Centers (CHCs)?

choices.text: Non-FRU CHCs should have 50 essential beds.
Non-FRU CHCs can be located in urban areas.
FRU-CHCs can be located in rural areas.
Elective surgeries will not be performed at FRU-CHCs.

questions.solution:
First Referral Unit - Community Health centers (FRU-CHCs) can be located in rural areas.

Community health centers (CHC) can be classified into the following types:

  • Non-FRU-CHCs - They are located in rural areas. They provide preventive, promotive, palliative, and rehabilitative services. They also have curative services for normal delivery, stabilization of common emergencies, etc.
  • FRU-CHCs are the first centers of referral from smaller centers such as sub-centers or primary health centers. They can be located in rural as well as urban areas. Apart from providing the abovementioned essential services, they also provide specialized services and elective surgeries. All the CHCs located in urban areas are FRU-CHCs.

In addition to the above centers, CHCs called Block Health Public Units (BHPU) may be located in the block headquarters. Apart from clinical and public health services, they have a health management information system (HMIS). They also help in decentralizing health services.

questions.text: A rural hilly area has a population of  40,000. How many Primary Health Centers (PHCs) should it have?
questions.solution:
A rural hilly area with a population of 40,000 should have 2 Primary Health Centers (PHCs).

According to the latest IPHS 2022 guidelines, in hilly areas, there should be one PHC for every 20,000 population. Since this village has a population of 40,000, it should have 2 PHCs.

questions.text: All of the following surgical procedures can be conducted in a Primary Health Center (PHC) except _____.
questions.solution:
Cholecystectomy is not a surgical procedure that is conducted in a PHC. The surgical procedures done in PHC include suturing of wounds, incision and drainage of abscesses, vasectomy, tubectomy, and hydrocelectomy.

Services provided under PHC:

  1. General services: OPD, teleconsultation services
  2. Emergency services
  3. 24x7 labor rooms
  4. Antenatal clinics, non-communicable diseases (NCD) clinics
  5. Rotational specialist clinics
  6. Surgical procedures:
    • Suturing of wounds
    • Incision and drainage of abscesses
    • Vasectomy, tubectomy, hydrocelectomy in PHCs with a functional minor OT, and standard infection-prevention protocols
  7. Antenatal care and services:
    • Detecting pregnancy 
    • Provision of ANC and counseling services
    • Identification, management, and referral of high-risk pregnancies
    • Detection of alarming signs during pregnancy and labor with timely and appropriate referral
    • Monitoring high-risk pregnancies
    • Management of malaria for pregnant women, as per National Center for Vector Borne Diseases Control (NCVBDC) guidelines
    • Management of tuberculosis during pregnancy
    • Management of mild/moderate anemia
    • Management of gestational diabetes mellitus, as per Government of India guidelines

questions.text: You are a medical officer in an Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC). The population of the place is 10,000. How many ASHA workers are needed for your UHWC?
questions.solution:
In a place with a population of 10,000, 5 ASHA workers are needed. 

There are two forms of Health and Wellness Centers in Sub-Health Centers.

  • Health and Wellness Centre - Sub-Health Center (HWC-SHC) in rural areas: It requires 1 ASHA per 1000 population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 3 + ASHAs.
  • Urban Health and Wellness Center (UHWC): It requires 1 ASHA per 2000 population and 1 ANM per 10000 population. Health and wellness center- Sub-Center 1 ASHA per 1,000 population or 1 ASHA per habitation in hilly/tribal areas. It has a total staff of 4 + ASHAs.

Functions of HWCs under Sub-Health Centers:

  • Provide primary care services
  • Deliver the 12 packages under CPHC
  • Serve as a platform for teleconsultation and widening the range of diagnostics
  • Serve as a fulcrum for services in National Health Programmes

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Health and Wellness Center - Primary Health Center (HWC-PHC). According to the IPHS 2022 guidelines, which of the following is incorrect regarding the essential manpower required for this PHC?
questions.solution:
Specialists like ophthalmologists are not included as essential manpower for a PHC. Specialists for medicine, obstetrics & gynecology, pediatrics, ophthalmology, etc. are essential manpower included under polyclinics.

According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) 2022 guidelines, a total of 12 staff is considered essential manpower for a PHC. They include 1 Medical Officer (MBBS), 2 staff nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker female/ANM, 1 health worker/health assistant (male), 1 health assistant (female)/lady health visitor, 1 laboratory technician, 1 data entry operator, 1 dresser, 1 accountant, and 1 sanitation staff. 

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh
